Line 24: Line 24:
Supported host operating systems include [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista]], [[Windows 7]], [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]], and [[OpenSolaris]]; there is also a port to [[FreeBSD]] (only OSE version).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.freebsd.org/VirtualBox |title=VirtualBox - FreeBSD Wiki |publisher=Wiki.freebsd.org |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> Supported guest operating systems include versions and derivations of [[Windows]], [[Linux]], [[BSD]], [[OS/2]], [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Guest_OSes |title=Guest_OSes |publisher=VirtualBox |date=2009-06-12 |accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> Since release 3.2.0, VirtualBox also allows limited virtualization of Mac OS X guests on Apple hardware.<ref>[http://lifehacker.com/5530521/virtualbox-32-beta-virtualizes-mac-os-x-on-macs VirtualBox 3.2 Beta Virtualizes Mac OS X (On Macs)], May 4, 2010, By Kevin Purdy, Lifehacker</ref>
Supported host operating systems include [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista]], [[Windows 7]], [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]], and [[OpenSolaris]]; there is also a port to [[FreeBSD]] (only OSE version).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.freebsd.org/VirtualBox |title=VirtualBox - FreeBSD Wiki |publisher=Wiki.freebsd.org |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> Supported guest operating systems include versions and derivations of [[Windows]], [[Linux]], [[BSD]], [[OS/2]], [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Guest_OSes |title=Guest_OSes |publisher=VirtualBox |date=2009-06-12 |accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> Since release 3.2.0, VirtualBox also allows limited virtualization of Mac OS X guests on Apple hardware.<ref>[http://lifehacker.com/5530521/virtualbox-32-beta-virtualizes-mac-os-x-on-macs VirtualBox 3.2 Beta Virtualizes Mac OS X (On Macs)], May 4, 2010, By Kevin Purdy, Lifehacker</ref>
â
According to 2010 surveys by LinuxJournal.com <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.linuxjournal.com/content/readers-choice-awards-2010 |title=2010 Linux Journal Readers' Choice Awards}}</ref> and LifeHacker.com <ref>{{cite web |url=http://lifehacker.com/5715803/best-virtual-machine-application-virtualbox |title=LifeHacker.com Best Virtual Machine Application}}</ref>, VirtualBox was the most popular virtualization product with over 50% of the vote.
+
According to 2010 surveys by LinuxJournal.com <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.linuxjournal.com/content/readers-choice-awards-2010 |title=2010 Linux Journal Readers' Choice Awards}}</ref> and [[LifeHacker.com]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://lifehacker.com/5715803/best-virtual-machine-application-virtualbox |title=LifeHacker.com Best Virtual Machine Application}}</ref>, VirtualBox was the most popular virtualization product with over 50% of the vote.
